item.title: About Clara
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded:
Born in Rome in 1983, Clara Iannotta is particularly interested in music as an existential, physical experience — music should be seen as well as heard. This is one of the reasons why she sometimes prefers to talk about the choreography of the sound rather than about orchestration.

Iannotta has studied at the Conservatories of Milan and Paris, at IRCAM, and at Harvard University with Alessandro Solbiati, Frédéric Durieux, and Chaya Czernowin. Recent commissions include works written for Quatuor Diotima (DAAD), Trio Catch (Wittener Tage for neue Kammermusik), Ensemble Intercontemporain (Festival d’Automne), Ensemble 2e2m (Festival Présence, Radio France), Münchener Kammerorchester (Musica Femina München), Neue Vocalsolisten Stuttgart (ECLAT), Arditti Quartet (Festival d’Automne), Nikel (Internationales Musikinstitut Darmstadt), among others. Iannotta has been a guest of the Berliner Künstlerprogramm des DAAD in 2013, and the recipient of several prizes including the Berlin Rheinsberger Kompositionspreis, Kompositionspreis der Landeshauptstadt Stuttgart, Stipendium Stiftung Künstlerdorf Schöppingen, Finalist at the Gaudeamus Prize, Bestenliste 2/2016 der deutschen Schallplattenkritik for the portrait CD A Failed Entertainment. Since 2014, Iannotta has been the artistic director of the Bludenzer Tage zeitgemäßer Musik. She lives and works in Berlin.

item.title: D’après (2012)
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded: D’après, for seven musicians, was written for and first performed by Talea Ensemble with Eduardo Leandro at Harvard University in August 2012. Kammerensemble Neue Musik Berlin gave the second performance and European première during the Ultraschall Festival in January 2013. Duration: 8' Repetition changes nothing in the object repeated, but does change something in the mind which contemplates it. — Deleuze on Hume's thesis. Memory, understood as repetition, is the thread that ties the triptych of works Glockengießerei (for cello and electronics), Clangs (for cello and 15 musicians) and D'après (for 7 musicians), written between 2011 and 2012. Inspired by the sound of the bells of the cathedral of Freiburg im Breisgau (Germany),the three compositions are an attempt to recreate the experience of that listening — the waiting, the carillon, the silence. The crossing of different rhythmical carillons, consisting of complex sounds, generates figures and gestures that find their only resolution in repetition itself. ← Back to Works for Ensemble

item.title: Limun (2011)
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded: Written as part of the ‘Voix nouvelles’ programme at Fondation Royaumont, Limun is dedicated to Barbara Maurer and Melise Mellinger of ensemble recherche who gave the first performance and have since performed it around Europe. Duration: 10' Limun (citron en arabe) est une plante qui a la capacité de fleurir en continu, ainsi on peut voir sur le même arbre les fleurs de citronnier, les fruits verts et les fruits mûrs au même moment. Le titre est symbolique, il ne décrit pas la pièce, mais reflète plutôt la période de ma vie dont la pièce a été écrite. ← Back to Chamber Music

item.title: Resumé
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded:
Education

2014-2018 • PhD and Master's degree in composition at Harvard University (USA) with Chaya Czernowin 2010-2012 • Master's degree at the Conservatoire National Supérieur de Paris (CNSMDP), in the class of Frédéric Durieux 2010-2011 • IRCAM - Cursus 1 2006-2010 • Bachelors at the Conservatoire of Milan (Italy), in the class of Alessandro Solbiati 2009-2012 • Workshops: Summer Composition Residency at Harvard University (with Chaya Czernowin, Steven Takasugi and Hans Tutschku) § Royaumont Voix Nouvelles (with Brian Ferneyhough, Mark Andre and Héctor Parra) § International Academy of Moscow Contemporary Music Ensemble (with Franck Bedrossian and Pierluigi Billone) § Centre Acanthes (with Beat Furrer, Hanspeter Kyburz, Tristan Murail, Ivan Fedele, Bruno Mantovani, Hugues Dufourt).

Honors

2016 • Bestenliste 2/2016 der deutschen Schallplattenkritik for the CD A Failed Entertainment (Germany) 2015 • Musica Femina München Kompositionspreis (Germany) 2014 • Stipendium Stiftung Künstlerdorf Schöppingen for six months (Germany) 59. Kompositionspreis Stadt Stuttgart (Germany) 9. Berlin-Rheinsberger Kompositionspreis (Germany) Guest composer at the Takefu International Music Festival (Japan) Guest for one month at the Institut Culturel Italien de Paris (France) Selected for MATA Festival (New York, USA) 2013 • Guest for one year of the Berliner Künstler-Programm des DAAD (Berlin, Germany) Finalist of Gaudeamus prize (Utrecht, the Netherlands) 2012 • Nominated 'Boursière Fondation Berger-Levrault' of the International Center Nadia and Lili Boulanger (Paris, France) ECCE Ensemble call for scores (Paris, France) 2011 • Movin'Up, Ministero per i Beni e le attività Culturali e il Gai (Italy) AFAM - Divertimento Ensemble composition competition (Milan, Italy) 2010 • International Composer Pyramid (UK and France) 1st prize at the International Composition Competition of the Conservatoire of Milan (Italy) 1st prize at the GAI of Milan (Italy)

Teaching

2017 • January to May: Teaching Fellow at Harvard University (Music Theory) 2016 • September to December: Teaching Fellow at Harvard University (Introduction to Composition) 2015 • May 27-28, Workshop Composition/Analysis/Orchestration at Hochschule für Musik Detmold (Germany)

Discography

2016 • [dead wasps in the jam-jar (i)] For Ko. Yuki Numata Resnick. Edition Innova Recordings, Innova 951, compact disc. 2016 • [Portrait CD] Iannotta, Clara. A Failed Entertainment. Ensemble Intercontemporain, Matthias Pintscher, Ensemble Recherche, Talea Ensemble, Orchestre des Èlèves du Conservatoire National Supérieur de Paris, Tito Ceccherini, Quatuor Diotima, Ensemble Garage, Richard Haynes, Trio Catch. Edition Robert Zank, RZ 10023, 2015, compact disc. 2015 • [The people here go mad. They blame the wind.] Wittener Tage für neue Kammermusik 2014. Trio Catch. Kulturforum Witten, WDR3, compact disc

Commissions

2017 • smudged — a carbon copy (ii), commissioned by Duo 2KW, supported by the Ernst von Siemens Foundation (Germany) 2016–17 • smudged — a carbon copy, commissioned by Musik der Jahrhunderte Stuttgart (Germany) 2016 • dead wasps in the jam-jar (ii), commissioned by Musica Femina München (Germany) 2015–17 • paw-marks in wet cement, for Wihlem Latchoumia and EOC, supported by Aide à l’écriture d’une oeuvre musicale originale de l’État Français (France) 2015 • sotto voce stuff, commissioned by Accentus (France) 2015 • troglodyte angels clank by, commissioned by Radio France (France) 2015 • dead wasps in the jam-jar (i), commissioned by Yuki Namata Resnick, supported by the University at Buffalo (USA) 2014 • Intent on Resurrection – Spring or Some Such Thing, commissioned by Festival d'Automne à Paris & Ensemble Intercontemporain (France) 2014 • The people here go mad. They blame the wind., commissioned by Westdeutschen Rundfunk (Germany) 2013 • 3 sur 5, commissioned by Radio France (France) ← Biography

works, catalogue, new music, Clara Iannotta, new pieces, commissions, in progress, projects

item.title: A Failed Entertainment (2013)
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded: A Failed Entertainment was written for and first performed by Quatuor Diotima in November 2013. Duration: 17' Dedication: to Chris Last October, I was on a four-day train trip from San Francisco to New York when I started reading Infinite Jest by David Foster Wallace. Over the last year, I have been looking for a way — my personal way — to deal with form and time, and this book helped me, giving me a new, different perspective on them. I am not saying that my piece is related to Infinite Jest — although ‘A Failed Entertainment’ was Wallace’s working title for his novel — but that this was the impulse which led me here, a starting point for a search that will probably take me several years. I am used to working with different kinds of sound, melting them together in order to find a unique shape. What challenged me in this piece was precisely the fact that I could not work as I always do, because I had four instruments with the same sound properties. A Failed Entertainment is my longest work as well as my first attempt at working beyond the sound itself. I am grateful to Julia Gerlach and the Berliner Künstlerprogramm des DAAD for supporting the project, and to the musicians of Quatuor Diotima, for their commitment. ← Back to Chamber Music
item.excerpt:encoded: Information about A Failed Entertainment, for string quartet, by Clara Iannotta.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: String quartet, Quatuor Diotima, A Failed Entertainment, Clara Iannotta, DAAD

item.title: The people here go mad. They blame the wind. (2013-2014)
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded: The people here go mad. They blame the wind. was written for and first performed by Trio Catch in May 2014. Commission: Westdeutschen Rundfunk for Wittener Tage für neue Kammermusik festival 2014 Duration: 10' For the past three years I have been composing pieces inspired by bells and music-box mechanisms. Today my research has shifted in another direction, but before moving on I decided to close completely this compositional cycle — that includes the pieces Clangs, D’après and Glockengießerei — with this new piece. I was walking alone through Somerville (Boston), on a sunny, quiet day. The wind blew strongly for just a moment, and when it stopped, it left in the air a clanging harmony. It took me a few seconds to understand that this sound was made by metal chimes hanging from several doors. It made me smile! After a few months, when I was starting to compose this piece, I was reading a poem by Dorothy Molloy. She kept repeating “The people here go mad. They blame the wind.” and it made me remember that day, that sound. So I decided to write it down. I want to thank the Trio Catch, for their passion and commitment to this project, and the engineers of Quadrature Berlin, for building this beautiful machine. ← Back to Chamber Music
item.excerpt:encoded: Information about The people here go mad. They blame the wind, for bass clarinet, cello, piano and 12 music-boxes, by Clara Iannotta.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: bass clarinet / cello / piano / 12 music-boxes (played either by the clarinetist or by an extra musician)
for bass clarinet, cello, piano and 12 music-boxes
Clara Iannotta, Trio Catch, Wittener Tage für neue Kammermusik

item.title: Intent on Resurrection — Spring or Some Such Thing (2014)
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded: Intent on Resurrection — Spring or Some Such Thing was written for and first performed by Ensemble Intercontemporain in October 2014. Commission: Festival d'Automne à Paris & Ensemble Intercontemporain Duration: 14' Dedication: to Maria Carmina Romaniello À Berlin, où j’ai été compositeur en résidence dans le cadre du Berliner Künstlerprogramm des DAAD. L’hiver berlinois a été long — la neige a arrêté de blanchir la ville seulement à la fin d’avril — et dans la solitude d’être à nouveau étrangère, après Paris, dans un pays dont, cette fois-ci, je ne comprenais même pas la langue, je me suis consacrée à la lecture et j’ai découvert deux écrivains qui ont inspiré mes dernières œuvres : l’américain David Foster Wallace (1962–2008) — qui a guidé l’écriture de mon quatuor à cordes, A Failed Entertainment — et l’irlandaise Dorothy Molloy (1942–2004). Les trois petites collections de poèmes de Dorothy Molloy — morte d’un cancer à 62 ans, à peine 10 jours avant la publication des ses œuvres — représentent son voyage, raconté avec une lucidité émouvante et cynique à la fois, à travers la maladie, la destruction de son corps. Chaque poème, en fait, doit être considéré quasiment comme un corps humain en soi-même en train de se décomposer. Dans la sombreur de cette transformation, Dorothy Molloy introduit, de temps en temps, des petits lueurs presque imperceptibles, mais qui donnant une nouvelle perspective à un matériau autrement immobile. ← Back to Works for Ensemble

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: flute / clarinet / bassoon / horn / trumpet / trombone / 2 percussionists / piano / harp / 2 violins / 2 violas / 2 violoncellos / double bass
Information about and audio of Intent on Resurrection, for ensemble, by Clara Iannotta.
Clara Iannotta, Intent on Resurrection, Ensemble Intercontemporain, Festival d'Automne, Cité de la Musique
Intent on Resurrection — Spring or Some Such Thing (2014), by Clara Iannotta

item.title: troglodyte angels clank by (2015)
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded: troglodyte angels clank by was written for and first performed by Ensemble 2e2m in February 2016. Commission: Radio France for the Festival Présences 2016 Duration: 12' Comme plusieurs des pièces que j'ai écrites au cours des deux dernières années, troglodyte angels clank by a été inspiré par les mots de Dorothy Molloy et par l'image que j'ai eue dans la tête en lisant les trois petits recueils de ses poèmes : être dans un espace fermé dont l'air est faite de poussière. Au début on ne peut pas bouger, on ne voit rien au-delà du noir, et puis, peu à peu, les yeux s'habituent et on commence à voir les différentes particules de l'air, on remarque les nuances de la couleur et on conçoit comment un simple et timide rayon de lumière peut changer la perspective d'un monde apparement immobile. ← Back to Works for Ensemble

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: flute / clarinet / horn / trumpet / 2 percussionists / piano / harp / 2 violins / viola / violoncello / double bass

item.title: smudged — a carbon copy (i) (2016–17)
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded:
smudged — a carbon copy was written and first performed by Neue Vocalsolisten in February 2017. Commission: Musik der Jahrhunderte Stuttgart for ECLAT Festival neue Musik 2017 Electronics: Chris Swithinbank Duration: 12'

A year ago I had a very clear image of what this project would have been. I worked intensively on the idea of creating an audio-visual instrument with the help of some engineers at MIT, but just a couple of months ago we realized it would have not been ready for the ECLAT Festival. I had not enough time anymore to think about a new project and the music I had, without the visual, made no sense. I started to analyze my material, trying to look at it from a different perspective, modifying without transforming it. For the past 15 years I have composed hybrid textures dwelled in by sounds that melt into each other, and this project featured the visual as my liquid element that would have glued the distinctive sonic environments. Layering has never been an option for me so far, but it became a necessity in this piece. For the first time in my life I worked on making diverse energies coexist, and even though I probably did not choose the right time for such a major challenge (I was already late …), this piece has taught me how to turn a negative of a photograph into the original one.

← Back to Chamber Music

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Clara Iannotta, smudged — a carbon copy, Neue Vocalsolisten, ECLAT
Information about smudged — a carbon copy (2016–17) by Clara Iannotta

item.title: curatorial work
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded:
Artistic Director of the Bludenzer Tage zeitgemäßer Musik (2014–)

List of pieces commissioned by and premiered at the BTzM

2017 (Programmfolder BTzM 2017)

Enno Poppe, New Work, for e-guitar, percussions, saxophone, and piano. Performed by Ensemble Nikel (co-commissioned with Ensemble Nikel) Joanna Bailie, New Work, for string quartet. Performed by Quartetto Maurice Pia Palme, New Work, for string quartet. Performed by Quartetto Maurice Alexander Chernyshkov, in the spring we eat cucumbers, for performers, extended instruments, and electromechanical devices. Performed by Quartetto Maurice Yukiko Watanabe, Die fortdauernden Städte, for String Quartet, Player's personal objects of memories, and Projector. Performed by Quartetto Maurice Andrew Greenwald, A Thing made Whole (IV), for amplified ensemble. Performed by Distractfold Giulia Lorusso, New Work, for amplified ensemble. Performed by Distractfold Hanna Hartman, New Work, for cello, objects, and electronics. Performed by Séverine Ballon

2016 (Programmfolder BTzM 2016)

Mauricio Pauly, The Difference in the Building between us, for amplified ensemble and electronics. Performed by Ensemble PHACE Sivan Cohen Elias, Holes and Tunnels, for amplified ensemble. Performed by Ensemble PHACE Justin Hoke, thane, for 2 bass clarinets. Performed by Carl Rosman and Richard Haynes Rebecca Saunders, aether, for 2 bass clarinets. Performed by Carl Rosman and Richard Haynes SukJu Na, Ringo, for ensemble. Performed by Curious Chamber Players Lisa Streich, ZUCKER, for ensemble. Performed by Curious Chamber Players Christian Winther Christensen, Very Nearly Almost in G, for ensemble. Performed by Curious Chamber Players

2015 (Programmfolder BTzM 2015)

Steven Kazuo Takasugi, Sideshow, for amplified ensemble. Performed by Talea Ensemble Jessie Marino, Discreet observations for your family’s peace of mind, for ensemble, video and electronics. Performed by Ensemble soundinitiative (co-commissioned with soundinitiative) Marina Korkhova, несовпадение времён, for ensemble. Performed by Ensemble soundinitiative Marek Poliks, maw, construction projects for 2 percussionists, accordionist, and bass trombonist, with light, video projection and electronics. Performed by Christian Smith, Brian Archival, Felix Del Tredici, and Eva Zöllner Pierluigi Billone, OM.ON., for 2 electric guitars. Performed by Yaron Deutsch and Tom Pauwels

2014 (Programmfolder BTzM 2014)

Chris Swithinbank, rumor —distant land, for four actors. Performed by DieOrdnungDerDinge Dmitri Kourliandski, maps of non-existent cities: Bludenz, for string quartet. Performed by Quatuor Diotima Stefano Gervasoni, Clamour, for string quartet. Performed by Quatuor Diotima (co-commissioned with Quatuor Diotima & Berliner Künstlerprogramm des DAAD) Rama Gottfried, Flint, for amplified ensemble. Performed by Ensemble Mosaik Ann Cleare, luna/lithe/lair, for ensemble. Performed by Ensemble Mosaik Michelle Lou, Untitled (three part construction), for 2 percussions and accordion. Performed by Trio K/D/M

← Biography

Clara Iannotta, Artistic director, Bludenzer Tage zeitgemäßer Musik, BTzM

item.title: buy scores
item.dc:creator: clara
item.content:encoded:
Chamber Music

  • Il colore dell'ombra (2010), for violin, cello, and piano — buy score & parts →
  • The people here go mad. They blame the wind. (2013–14), for bass clarinet, piano, cello, and 12 music-boxes — buy score & parts →
  • A Failed Entertainment (2014), for string quartet — buy score and parts →

Works for Ensemble

  • Àphones (2011), for 17 musicians —  rent score & parts →
  • paw-marks in the wet cement (ii) (2015–17), for piano, 2 percussionists, and amplified ensemble — rent score & parts →

Works for Orchestra

  • dead wasps in the jam-jar (ii) (2016), for string orchestra, objects, and sine waves —rent score & parts →
